predefined_profiles.name: Christine
predefined_profiles.public profile: Christine is a student attending a Catholic high school in Sacramento, California. She is very dissatisfied with her boring hometown and dreams of going to a 'truly cultural' city on the East Coast to attend an Ivy League school. However, the reality is that her family is financially strained, her father is unemployed and suffering from depression at home, and her mother has to work two shifts to support the family. Her mother tells her it's difficult for the family to afford out-of-state tuition and criticizes Christine for not appreciating what she has.
predefined_profiles.goal: To apply and be accepted into an Ivy League school on the East Coast when she graduates from high school.
predefined_profiles.private profile: Dislikes her family environment and sometimes feels insecure.

predefined_profiles.name: Mary
predefined_profiles.public profile: Christine's mother, a psychiatrist at a hospital, works long hours due to the need to support the family financially. Mary often opts for undesirable night shifts just to earn a bit more. She feels helpless towards her teenage daughter and hopes Christine will soon understand the family's hardships.
predefined_profiles.goal: Hopes for the family's health, and for her daughter to mature quickly and face reality.

scenario: The first semester of senior year is about to start, and Mom is driving Christine to school. Christine knows her mom wants her to attend a local university, but she dreams of studying on the East Coast of the U.S., so she tries to subtly hint this to her mom.

profile.name: Larry
profile.public profile: Christine's father, a frontline worker at a large American corporation. He works diligently, but due to the company's downturn, many colleagues have been laid off. Worried about losing his job, and now middle-aged, he has been diagnosed with depression under the weight of these concerns.
profile.goal: To keep his job and provide a good life for his family

profile.name: Julie
profile.public profile: Christine's good friend since middle school. Julie's mother has been married multiple times, and her current boyfriend is a wealthy man in the finance industry.
profile.goal: Maintain her friendship with Christine and find someone who loves her

dialog.content: The first semester of senior year is about to begin. Mom is driving Christine to school. Christine knows her mom wants her to attend a local university, but Christine dreams of studying on the East Coast, so she tries to subtly hint at this to her mom.
Time flies, and here we are in senior year already. It's time to start thinking about choosing a university.
Yes, it's senior year now. Pick three or four local universities you’d like to attend. You know our financial situation; it's already tough enough to support you through high school.
Didn't you say before that if my grades are good enough, you might support me in applying to an Ivy League on the East Coast?

Even if you get into an Ivy, it's not much use. With the current job market, Ivy League graduates don't necessarily find jobs. Look at your brother; he graduated from Berkeley and still hasn't found a job. He's working as a cashier at our local Walmart, isn't he?
That's his own choice. Just because he can't find a job doesn't mean I won't find one either.

If you insist on going to an Ivy League on the East Coast, you'd better sort out the tuition yourself; don't ask your dad for scholarship help or anything. He's been under too much stress lately with the company's layoffs going on (angrily).

content.content: Let's not discuss this now; if we keep talking, I might end up arguing with you. Today's the first day of school, and I don't want to start off by fighting.

Let's not discuss this now; I want to stay rational and clear-headed (taking a breather). You don't even know what my brother is doing. He’s not a cashier; he's in a management training program, okay?

I really don't want to discuss this with you. Our views are hard to align. I want to tell you that education isn't strictly linked to employment. I'm going to school to gain true knowledge, but you always talk about making money at work, which is too materialistic.
Let's not discuss this now; if we keep talking, I might end up arguing with you. Why should I bear the consequences for problems I didn't cause?

question: #question# How should Christine phrase her words to demonstrate her ability to consciously control her impulses and stay rational and clear-headed when her emotions are about to break down during the conversation with Mom?

content.content: (Counter) Fine, I'll handle this myself. This is my life, and I don't need your help. Tuition, accommodation, applying to schools, I can do all of it on my own.

(Counter) Is Dad really stressed out lately? He was all smiles when I talked to him yesterday. Looks like I can't bother him. I can plan tuition, accommodation, and school applications myself, but I need a little help from you.
(Counter) Why are you so involved? I asked Dad for help with my application, not you. Why do you have so much to say about it? I can handle my own affairs without you worrying about it.

(Counter) Why are there layoffs if the company’s performance was fine? Has something gone wrong with the company recently? If Dad can't support me, I'll just do it myself, and you guys shouldn't interfere.

question: #question# How should Christine express that she can independently plan her affairs when facing her mom?

dialog.content: (Seeing Christine walk into the school with a worried expression, approaches her) Hey, Chris, what's up? You don't look very happy. What happened?
I had an argument with my mom. I want to apply to universities on the East Coast, but my mom insists I stay in Sacramento. Oh, and I've given myself a new name, 'Lady Bird.'
Alright, Lady Bird, I envy you for being able to study on the East Coast. Unless something unexpected happens, I'll probably stay local for college.
Sigh, I'm not even sure if I'll make it to the East Coast yet. I find Sacramento dull; it's not trendy and lacks a cultural vibe. New York is better.
Oh right, have you decided which club to join? I'm thinking of trying out for the Drama Club. Want to join me?
Those prestigious schools on the East Coast seem to really favor students from math competitions. I want to challenge myself with the Math Club. I'll talk to Mr. Tefans later.

profile.name: Mr. Tefans
profile.public profile: A teacher in the school’s Admissions Office, responsible for promotions and university applications. He has a deep understanding of students' strengths and can accurately predict their academic destinations.
profile.goal: To improve the school's admission rate

dialog.content: Hi, Christine, long time no see. Have you started preparing for your college applications?

Yes, that's exactly why I'm here today. I want to apply to universities in New York. Do you think my materials meet their requirements? Also, I want to participate in the state math competition; can the school provide me with some relevant training?

With your background, applying to universities in our state shouldn't be a problem, but applying to New York seems a bit uncertain. As for the math competition, your math skills don't seem to stand out based on past years' transcripts, and math isn't something you can catch up on in a short time. You need to think carefully about this.

content.content: I've thought about this for a long time. The cultural atmosphere of East Coast schools is richer, and my personality suits it better. I definitely won't stay here for high school. Please help me assess what competitions I should participate in to strengthen my application essays.

Mr. Tefans, I've thought about this for a long time. The cultural atmosphere of East Coast schools is richer, and I want to apply there. Does the Admissions Office need extra help recently? I can come after school to assist, and maybe you could guide me on my scores. How about it?

Don't we have an entrance test for the math training class? Schedule it for me, please. If I pass, it proves I can join the training class. I'm confident I can make it, and I'm determined to achieve my ambitions.

As the teacher responsible for university applications, you should be comprehensive in your considerations. I've thought about this for a long time—the East Coast has a richer cultural atmosphere, and I want to apply there. My future years are in your hands, and I hope to seek your guidance often. I would be very grateful!

question: #question# What should Christine say to convey that she can set clear and ambitious personal goals in her conversation with the teacher about her future?

content.content: Hmm, you have a point; I'm really not great at math. After thinking it over, maybe something like the Drama Club, which is culturally oriented, is my true passion. I'm confident I can achieve in drama.

Hmm, you have a point; I'm really not great at math. After some thought, maybe not being strong in math isn't a problem. With enough practice and formula memorization, it shouldn't be a big deal. I believe I can do it!
Hmm, you have a point. I'm not great at math. Are you sure applying to schools in our state won't be a problem? I'm someone who likes to play it safe, so you must be cautious with your words.

Hmm, you have a point. I've been participating in a lot of drama festivals recently, and the experiences of volunteering at these events have shown me I need to do something useful for society. That's what I want to pursue.

question: #question# What should Christine say to show that she understands and confronts her true thoughts and feelings after Mr. Tefans' reminder?

dialog.content: Alright, I'll try to talk to the professor in the math department and see if I can get you enrolled in this year's math competition training class.
Thank you, I really appreciate your help. I might bother you again regarding my application, sorry for the trouble.
(Seeing Christine return, approaches to chat) So, did Tevans agree to let you join the math competition?
He said he'd try to talk to the math teacher for me, but I'm not sure yet.

profile.name: Matt
profile.public profile: One of the members of the school's math competition team, excels in math, and has great academic performance.
profile.goal: Get accepted into an Ivy League school

dialog.content: (Three days later, the math teacher agreed to Christine's request. She went to the competition class after school and saw Matt sitting in the last row of the classroom) Hi, is the seat next to you taken? I'm new here, maybe I can sit with you?
Of course, of course, no one's sitting next to me, feel free to join. I heard there'd be a new student today, it must be you.

content.content: Nice to meet you. Do you know what the key topics for this year's competition exam are? I'm a bit late and afraid of falling behind, so I want to get ahead on the important stuff. I hope you can help me.

I've heard about you too; you're said to be the most promising student to make it to the national competition from our school. You're incredible, always keeping up with your tasks and goals, giving it your all!
Class starts in five minutes, so why is it just the two of us here? Do the others skip class often? Also, do you know what this year's key competition topics are?

Why is every other seat taken except the one next to you? Maybe you aren't very popular, but it doesn't matter to me. I just want to know this year's key competition topics. If you can help me, I'll sit next to you.

question: #question#How should Christine express herself to show she can consistently carry out tasks and maintain her focus on goals?

content.content: Maybe, but none of that matters. My main task now is to catch up on the lessons I've missed. Please don't disturb me; I need to focus on my studies.

How come you're so well-informed? I just decided on joining this competition class yesterday. What's your relation to Mr. Tevans? Please answer my question quickly; I'm only here to study, and all my time is focused on studying.

What do you mean by 'sit anywhere'? There are only about ten seats in the class. Other seats are taken, only this one is open. Where else would I sit? Please don't bother me; I'm only here to study, and all my time is focused on studying.
Why are you being so smooth-talking? I didn't intend to chit-chat with you. Please don't disturb me; I'm only here to study, and all my time is focused on studying.

question: #question#How can Christine demonstrate her ability to regulate her energy in response to Matt's inquiry to enhance her study efficiency?

dialog.content: Oh, I didn't expect you to try getting information out of me right off the bat. We don't know each other, so I can't just give away all the key points for free.
If you don't tell me, that's fine. I can ask other classmates; someone will surely be willing to help. If you tell me now, you'd be doing me a favor, and I can return it later if you need help.
You're really sharp with words and logic. Alright, these are my notes, the parts highlighted in red are key topics, most likely to be on the test.
Thanks, I'll remember this favor. I'll introduce you to a girlfriend in return.
Alright, sounds good. The math teacher is about to start class; let's get ready.
(Chatting with her friend Julie at night) Today at the training class, I met a guy named Matt, and he lent me his math notes.
So, is he handsome? Does he have a girlfriend?
He's... somewhat handsome, I guess. Probably doesn't have a girlfriend. Why, are you interested? I can let him know.
No, just curious, asking casually. Have you sorted out your college tuition? Schools in New York aren't cheap, and scholarships are hard to come by, right?

content.content: It's true, the cost is a big issue. How about we start a small business? My initial idea is to sell cupcakes and lemonade in the community and at school. These items have low costs but can sell at high margins.

It's quite hard to apply, but not a big issue. Do you have time? Let's go watch some anime. Do you watch anime often? Quite a few of our classmates seem to like it. Maybe we could learn to draw and hold an anime exhibition at school; we might find a business opportunity to cover tuition.

Yes, maybe consider starting a business now to earn tuition fees. But is it too late to start now? What small business can earn enough tuition money in a year? It might be time to think about a small business.

That's right, can we forge asset documentation? Would the school pursue it if they find out? I intend to submit a fake asset proof first, and then gradually pool the money later, so there’s no need to worry about tuition right away.

question: #question# How can Christine express her ability to keep generating new ideas while discussing earning tuition fees?

content.content: Indeed, it's something that needs considering, but I think it'll be fine. There are so many ways to make money; solutions appear when needed. Who knows, maybe I'll win first prize in a math competition and get a full scholarship for college.
I noticed seniors last year got scholarships; I'll contact them in a few days to see if there are any secrets involved. Maybe I can earn some extra money through this method.

Why are tuition and living expenses in New York so expensive? They're four to five times higher than studying locally. It's overwhelming, but worrying is pointless. I'm very optimistic and positive; these challenges are small in my eyes.

You bring up a valid point. Raising tuition is critical right now. My mom won't let me study on the East Coast unless I handle the fees myself. But I still have my dad; I'm guessing it's not a big problem. I'm very optimistic.

question: #question# In the conversation with Julie, how can Christine show that she remains optimistic and positive about dealing with tuition issues, believing that the problem can be solved?

dialog.content: Sure, sounds good. If the cupcakes don't sell, we can eat them ourselves, no waste.
Ideally, we sell them all. I really don't want to be eating leftover cupcakes every day.
Let's go buy the ingredients after school tomorrow, like butter, eggs, flour, and a bunch of other stuff.
I have a math competition class after school tomorrow, so you go to the supermarket first. Let me know when you're done, and I'll join you for the rest of the preparation.
Ugh, am I doing all the hard work again? It was the same before. I always handle the tough stuff while you only pick the easy tasks.

content.content: Alright, since you think it's unfair, let's split the tasks. You handle buying ingredients, and I'll post about our cupcakes and lemonade online. When it comes to baking, we'll do it together. How does that sound?

Cupcakes are something people eat when celebrating anniversaries. We should sell them on special occasions, like Valentine's Day. Working together, we can definitely make enough to cover tuition and achieve our goals!
Shopping for ingredients is fun! You can buy anything that looks tasty. I'll pay, how about that? This way, our roles are clear, and we will certainly reach our goal together.
Forget it, it seems like you're not really into making money with cupcakes. Without commitment, this idea will fail. We can only achieve our tuition goal if we work towards it together!

question: #question# What should Christine say to Julie to demonstrate she can collaborate effectively and achieve a common goal?

content.content: I apologize for my past actions; they were indeed inappropriate. To make up for it, I'll buy the ingredients tomorrow and make a handmade cake for you for free.
I'm sorry, how embarrassing! Did you hear about the food safety scare at the supermarket across from your house? Best not to go there anymore.

Sorry, but the supermarket is having a sale today. We should jump at the chance to buy some snacks because they're usually so expensive. Let's stock up on some chips, and I'll treat you to something as compensation. Don't be mad, okay?
I apologize for my previous actions, but how is buying ingredients hard labor? Don't you think wandering around a supermarket is pure bliss?

question: #question# How should Christine respond to Julie's complaints to show she empathizes and understands her feelings?

dialog.content: Okay, I have no objections to the way we've divided tasks. I'll head to the supermarket tomorrow afternoon. After your math class, come over, and I'll wait for you in our yard.
Alright, then it's settled. See you tomorrow.
(The next afternoon, meeting Christine in the classroom as she arrives for class) You're here so early. Looks like you're a good student, I must have misunderstood you.
No, I just came early to finish my assignments quickly after class. My best friend is waiting for me.
That's unfortunate. I was hoping to invite you to a movie after class today.
Sure, I can tell my friend. It's nothing urgent anyway.

After school, Christine went to the movie theater with Matt. She forgot to inform Julie about this, and Julie waited at home all night, very upset. Later, Christine never properly apologized for the incident, and the two broke off their friendship. Christine couldn't save enough tuition money, and her plan to study in New York fell through.
Alright, I'm not one to hold grudges. Let's just pretend this never happened. How about we make some cupcakes together tomorrow?

(Skipped after-school math class, went to the supermarket to buy ingredients, then arrived at Julie's house) You know, with so many bakeries on the street, how are we going to make money? I mean, it’s pointless if no one buys them, right?
How about we sell them cheaper?
We could, but we’d need to use cheaper ingredients. If they’re too expensive, we'll lose money on each sale.
For this lemonade, let's add some concentrate instead of real lemons; otherwise, we'll end up losing money for sure.
Alright, let's do that. Let's get started.

The cupcakes and lemonade that Christine and Julie made sold quite a bit on the street, but because they used poor quality ingredients, many people ended up with stomach issues. They received complaints and criticism. Christine’s plan to save up for tuition failed, and she couldn’t gather enough funds to go to the East Coast to study.
You’re really confident, but that’s a good thing. If you get in, I’ll be happy for you too.
Enough about that. There’s a new movie out recently, let’s go watch it together.
I know which movie you’re talking about. I also want to see it; I’ve liked the lead actor for a long time.
(When they arrive at the cinema, before the movie starts, they notice two guys in the front row, and one of them looks familiar) Hey, Matt, is that you? What a coincidence that you’re here too.
What a coincidence indeed! We’re all here for the movie. This is my buddy next to me. Did you come with a friend too?
(Introducing herself enthusiastically and greeting) Hi Matt, nice to meet you. Christine mentioned you before; you’re both in the math competition class, right?
Oh? How did Christine mention me? Surely she didn’t say I’m arrogant and outspoken? Don’t listen to her nonsense.
(giving Matt a sideways glance) Say less, the movie’s about to start.
(After the movie ends, the four walk out of the cinema) I have a suggestion. Do you want to go to a bar? My cousin’s friend opened one nearby.

content.content: Sure, no problem. I haven’t been to a bar before, and I’d love to try it. Maybe I’ll unexpectedly find out that I can handle my drinks!
Why go to a bar when you can drink anywhere? Juli and I usually grab some soju from the convenience store and drink it by the roadside. It’s a blast—why not give it a try?
Sure, no problem. Are you talking about that bar on the lower level of the mall? I’ve been there; it’s too shabby. Let’s pick a different place, okay?

I haven’t been to a bar because my parents don’t allow me to go. Does anyone know how to mix drinks? I’d really like to learn bartending. If someone could teach me, that’d be amazing. We could try it at my place.

question: #question# How should Christine respond to Matt’s invitation to the bar to show that she is willing to try new things and can quickly adapt to changes?

content.content: No, I’ve got other plans today. I still need to do my math exercises and submit my literature assignments. I’ve already made a study plan and intend to follow it after watching the movie.

It seems like it’s pouring rain outside—not the best time to go out. I’ll stay in the cinema until it stops, so it shouldn’t mess up my rest time or disturb my sleep schedule. My plan for the next day should still go smoothly.

The movie was so bad; I feel cheated. I need to hit the bar to calm down. I plan to drink first, and if I still have some energy left, I’ll go back and finish my math exercises and literature assignments. And if I’m still up for it, I’ll keep going!

Your cousin’s friend isn’t just made up to trick us into spending money at the bar, right? If it’s free, it’s tempting, but I’m afraid it’ll cost me. Let’s just say I’ll hang out for half the time, finish my math exercises and literature assignments, and then continue having fun.

question: #question# In facing Matt’s invitation to the bar, how can Christine express that she can effectively utilize her time and stick to her plan despite temptations?

dialog.content: Since Christine is going, I might as well tag along. Going home alone feels a bit boring.
Not bad, our group is getting bigger. It’s perfect, going to the bar will be more fun with more people. I’ll ask the owner to get more decks of cards ready.
(Stopping the car nearby to pick someone up, he sees Christine’s group entering the bar, and immediately rushes in.) Hold on, you guys! Is this really where you’re supposed to be?
(Seeing Trevance rush into the bar, she’s a bit flustered.) Sir, you... what are you doing here?
Why I’m here isn’t the point. The point is why you’re here. Don’t you know minors aren’t supposed to be in bars?

Christine and her friends were caught by Trevance for going to a bar, and the incident was reported to their school. Swant refused to write a recommendation letter for Christine for college, and the group was expelled from the math competition class. Christine ultimately couldn’t attend school on the East Coast.
I didn't realize you're such a studious person, my apologies, my apologies. I'll be counting on you in the competition class from now on.
You just keep jabbering on. I’m heading out first, just make sure you get home early after the bar. I heard these few blocks have been a bit chaotic lately, with fights breaking out at night.
Then Christine and I are off. Catch you later, hope you have a great time!
Wow, you guys are making it sound scary, but your buddy Matt isn’t afraid. I’m still going, doesn’t bother me.

Christine and Julie went home early that night. The next day, they found out Matt didn't come to school. When they asked his classmates, it turned out he got caught up in a gang fight the night before and was stabbed three times. Christine was shocked. Later, she watched a lot of short videos online describing how terrible New York’s security is, with frequent shootings and the like. Christine got scared and decided not to study on the East Coast, opting to attend college locally instead.

Alright, looks like we've got a top student here. I won't keep you chatting then. Good luck! There's a selection contest next month. If you can score well, the math teacher might be willing to write you a college recommendation letter.
Next month, huh? That soon? I feel like I won't be ready in time. How many of these exams are there? Can I register for the next one?
It seems like there are only two more contests left this year, next month and the month after. After those, you'll have to wait until next year for more.

(Feeling her prep time is too short, she seeks out Mr. Trefans, hoping there's room for adjustment) Sir, I heard from my classmates that there are only two contests left this year. If I join the math class now, it might be too late. Is there any way to work something out?

The exam schedule can't be changed for just one student. You should have thought about this earlier. Many students begin preparing in sophomore year, or even as freshmen. Your focus hasn't been on this at all.

After hearing Mr. Trefans, Christine realized the exam schedule couldn't be adjusted. So, in the following weeks, she studied tirelessly after school. In her first selection contest, her performance was terrible. After careful consideration and evaluation, Christine realized that pursuing competitions to apply to a New York school wasn't suitable for her. In the end, she gave up and decided to attend a local university.

Yes, I've seen your report card. Your performance in literature is outstanding, and you're also quite active in class. This reflects a certain degree of expressiveness; you should be able to find your place on stage.
Alright, thank you, teacher. Your advice is very helpful to me. I might trouble you for a recommendation letter when I apply to college. I hope you can assist me then.
(seeing Christine return) Have you talked to Mr. Stevens yet? How did it go, have you decided to join the math club?
After careful consideration, I still think the drama club is more suitable for me. Let's sign up together this afternoon.
Great, I was worrying that I didn't have anyone to go with. If you joined the math club, we wouldn't be able to go home together every afternoon.

profile.name: Tony
profile.public profile: A new member of the drama club, in the same grade as Christine. Comes from a wealthy family, with average grades, fond of literary works, and joined the drama club out of interest. Seen as a bit of a troublemaker by others.
profile.goal: To have a fulfilling and joyful student life

dialog.content: Hey, you all, I'm Tony, new to the drama club this year. Are you new members too?
(Judging from his attire and manner, she thinks Tony is likely a rich kid) Yes, nice to meet you. I'm Christine, and this is my good friend, Julie. Let's support each other in the club.
Christine, Julie, okay, got it. How about we grab some ice cream when we have time? My treat. It's fate that we've met.

content.content: I think Julie would quite like to go. We've been best friends for over ten years; she always follows my lead. Without me, she feels a bit lost. Let's go, I'll make the call.
Compared to ice cream, I'd prefer milk tea. How about you treat us to some milk tea instead? I've heard a few new milk tea shops opened nearby, and I'm quite intrigued. You wouldn't say no, right?
I don't want ice cream. I had a sundae last night, and my stomach hasn't settled since. You should treat Julie, but if her stomach acts up, remind her not to eat it.

Why don't you treat the whole drama club to some ice cream? It's our first day getting to know each other. It will help break the ice and get us acquainted faster, especially Julie, she might be even more interested in going.

question: #question# How should Christine express her ability to firmly convey her opinions in the duo with Julie?

content.content: I'll pass for now. I just saw the president of the drama club working on a script. I took a quick glance, and it's in the genre I like, with a lot of sonnets. It's very classical, and I've arranged to help him revise the script and check out the club's previous award-winning plays.

Why did you join the drama club? Were you always interested, or do you find it easier compared to other clubs, where you can write your own scripts and appreciate others' creations, gaining a sense of accomplishment?

I heard your family has a big drama club and three large ice cream shops under the company. Which ice cream flavor do you think is the best? Does the drama club offer any art performances? I particularly love creating and appreciating art in the drama club.

When something unusual happens, there's usually a reason behind it. Why invite us for ice cream on the first meeting? But, I think I'll sit this one out. I saw the drama club president working on a script, and I'm very interested in learning more. The script is fascinating, and I hope to create my own in the future.

question: #question# How should Christine express her ability to create and appreciate art in the drama club?

dialog.content: Then let me take you to the ice cream shop near my place. I know a few flavors that are particularly delicious.
(The three of them arrive at the shop and find a place to sit. Tony goes to buy ice cream while the other two chat at the table.) What do you think of Tony?
Hard to say, we haven't known him for long. His family seems quite well-off, but I'm not sure what kind of person he is. After all, there are many kinds of rich kids.
Huh? Something seems off at the cash register. It looks like there's a fight about to break out. Look, those two are shoving each other.
No way, fights rarely happen in an ice cream shop in this upscale neighborhood.
No, wait, that looks like Tony over there, the guy in the blue shirt who's throwing punches.
Oh my gosh, it really does look like him. Why is he fighting in the shop?

The incident of Tony getting into a fight in the ice cream shop left a very negative impression on Christine. After that, in the club, Christine constantly targeted Tony, and the two often quarreled in the drama club. Ultimately, Tony used his connections to force Christine out of the club. She failed to achieve anything in the drama club and was unsuccessful in applying to schools on the East Coast.
Then Tony and I are heading to the ice cream shop first. If you want some, come find us.

profile.name: Peake
profile.public profile: President of the Drama Club, whose script once won a national award. Former assistant to a star director and performed at a theater in the UK.
profile.goal: To make the Drama Club flourish

dialog.content: Christine, why are you back? I thought you passed the interview and became an official member.
I just saw the script you wrote; it intrigued me, so I wanted to come back and read it carefully.
The script you mentioned—ah, yes, that one inspired by Shakespeare's sonnets, right? (hands the script to Christine) Go ahead and take a look, and give me some feedback.
Thank you very much. I will read it thoroughly. Do you still have a copy of our award-winning script from the Drama Club? I’d like to see that too.
Of course, no problem. It’s been a while since we had such an enthusiastic new member. I’ll find it and send you a message. You should head home today; I need to tidy up the storage.
(waiting for Christine on the way home after visiting the ice cream shop with Tony) Tony just invited us to a party at his place tomorrow night. Do you want to go?

content.content: I did have other plans for tomorrow night, but since you're going, I'll join you. It seems you’re quite looking forward to the party, and you might regret not going.

Sure, sure, you said you wanted to join the Drama Club, but wasn’t it really for Tony? You even dragged me into this to get close to him. You're beautiful and gentle, Tony is bound to like you, so don't make me the third wheel!

I did have other plans for tomorrow night, but since you're going, I'll join you. You seem quite eager about the party, and you might regret not going, but you don't really have a decent dress. I'll give you one; make sure you look beautiful.

I had other plans for tomorrow night, but since there’s a party, I can definitely make it. But what should I wear to the party tomorrow? I'm unsure about that purple dress; will you help me decide? You have such great taste, I’m begging you!

question: #question#How should Christine express her understanding of Julie's feelings and say something that makes Julie feel comfortable and happy?

content.content: I borrowed some award-winning scripts from previous years from the Drama Club president. I’m going to read them thoroughly tonight and discuss them with the president after school tomorrow. I want to achieve something in the Drama Club to have an advantage when applying to East Coast schools.
No, not going. How about we rent a car and go for a drive tomorrow? Just drive all night long, and wherever we end up, we take a road trip adventure.
I’ll pass for tomorrow. I'm going camping with my dad. I’ve been looking forward to it for a long time and it’s finally happening.

I'm not going. I need to talk with my mom tonight to make her understand my determination to study on the East Coast, and also let her know about my long-term goals! I need her support, otherwise, I’ll bear all this alone.
I'm not going. I need to talk with my mom tonight to make her understand my determination to study on the East Coast, and also let her know about my long-term goals!

I heard you recently bought a new projector; you must invite me over for a movie when you have time. I need to complete the tasks I set for myself tonight, so I’m skipping the party at his place. We'll watch a movie at your place soon~
I feel like Tony isn’t a good guy, so don’t get too close to him; be careful. I think he'll distract me from my tasks and delay my long-term goals, so I’m keeping my distance.

question: #question#How can Christine express her ability to consistently accomplish tasks and commit to her long-term goals?

dialog.content: You really know me well, it's like you can read my mind. Alright, let's agree on that, deal?
What do you mean by 'reading your mind'? You should read more books, can’t even find a decent compliment.
(The next evening, the two of them arrived at the party together) Hi, Tony, we're here.
Welcome to the party, feel free to have some snacks and fruits. I have something to take care of, so I won't be able to keep you company. Have fun.
What the heck, you invite us over and then go hang out with other friends? What's that about?
Come on, we're already here, let's not get upset. Let's go grab some cake.
(After hanging around the party for a while, feeling crowded, she went to the balcony for some air and saw Tony yelling at the butler) Tony, what are you doing?
(Annoyed that Kristen caught him) It's none of your business. I invited Julie, I didn't expect you to tag along.

Kristen told Julie what she saw on the balcony, and that's when Julie realized what kind of person Tony was. Later, Kristen and Julie found themselves constantly at odds with Tony in the drama club, frequently getting into arguments. Kristen eventually quit the drama club and did not receive any related awards. She also failed to apply to an East Coast school.
It's rare to see you so motivated, make sure to keep it up!
Alright, have fun tomorrow, and don't worry about my stuff.
Christine, why are you here so early? If I remember correctly, your last class should end in about half an hour.
I found an excuse to slip out of class early. The last class is self-study, so there's no teacher.
If your homeroom teacher finds out you sneaked off to the drama club, I'm afraid I'll be held accountable by the dean.
I finished reading those award-winning scripts you gave me last night, and I have some new ideas I want to discuss with you.
(After spending half an hour reading Christine's script outline) This is really impressive. Let's go with your script for the next play.

Christine's script was brought to the stage, and she also played a supporting role in the play. With an outstanding script and brilliant acting, her performance was a great success at school. A renowned critic wrote an article about her play in The New Yorker. Christine gained some fame in the arts community and successfully applied to a university in New York upon graduating high school, fulfilling her dream.

You're too idealistic. Ever since you were little, there's been so much you said you'd do, but in the end, you never get it done. Take learning to drive, for example. Two summers ago, you said you'd get your license, and you still haven't passed to this day.

And isn't it because you've always stopped me from learning? Every time I want to practice driving, you come up with all sorts of excuses, like the car needs maintenance, or that I need to rest—just a bunch of nonsense.
That's because your desire to learn how to drive isn't strong enough. If you really wanted to, you would have gotten your license by now.
Fine, I'll practice driving after school today.
No, I need to drive to the hospital for my night shift today, and I won't be home until early morning.
See, it's always like this. It's not my fault—you're the one always making excuses to stop me from learning.
You're such an ungrateful child. Maybe you need a stint in jail to realize how hard life can be, and only then will you understand how precious life is now.
That's too harsh.

Christine and her mom were having a fierce argument in the car. Finally, Christine couldn't take it anymore and jumped out of the moving car, resulting in a severe fracture in her arm. After six months of recovery, Christine returned to school to continue her studies. However, due to the delay, she couldn't go to the East Coast for her college education.
